comment: An aggressive first move.
Bishop's Opening.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Bc4 Nf6
comment: If 3. Nc3 then 3... Nxe4 4. Nxe4 d5 and Black has an equal game or better.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Bc4 Nf6 3. d3 Nc6
comment: Also good is 3... c6 preparing for ... d5.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Bc4 Nf6 3. d3 Nc6 4. Nc3
comment: Developing and keeping open the option of 5. f4 which would be impossible after 4. Nf3.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Bc4 Nf6 3. d3 Nc6 4. Nc3 Bc5
comment: A good developing move. Also playable was 4... Bb4.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Bc4 Nf6 3. d3 Nc6 4. Nc3 Bc5 5. f4 d6 6. f5
comment: This move cramps Black who cannot immediately play the natural rejoinder d5. White can proceed with a kingside attack while Black can pursue a queenside counterattack and strive to play ...d5. A major disadvantage of 6. f5 is that it takes the pressure off of Black's center.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Bc4 Nf6 3. d3 Nc6 4. Nc3 Bc5 5. f4 d6 6. f5 Nd4
comment: Black prepares his counterattack which consists of ...c6, ...b5, and ... a5.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Bc4 Nf6 3. d3 Nc6 4. Nc3 Bc5 5. f4 d6 6. f5 Nd4 7. Bg5
comment: Pinning the knight and threatening to break up Black's kingside pawn formation with 8. Nd5 and 9. Nxf6+.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Bc4 Nf6 3. d3 Nc6 4. Nc3 Bc5 5. f4 d6 6. f5 Nd4 7. Bg5 c6
comment: Preparing for the queenside attack and preventing 8. Nd5. Black threatens 8... b5 9. Bb3 a5 (Threatening 9... a4 trapping the biship) 10. a3 Nxb3 and White has a weakend pawn position and has exchanged his powerful bishop for a knight.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Bc4 Nf6 3. d3 Nc6 4. Nc3 Bc5 5. f4 d6 6. f5 Nd4 7. Bg5 c6 8. a3 b5 9. Ba2 Qb6
comment: Supporting the queenside attack and creating threats on the a7-g1 diagonal.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Bc4 Nf6 3. d3 Nc6 4. Nc3 Bc5 5. f4 d6 6. f5 Nd4 7. Bg5 c6 8. a3 b5 9. Ba2 Qb6 10. Nf3 a5
comment: White would like to castle now but that would allow Black to move the knight on d4 checking with the bishop. For example, 11. 0-0 Nxf3+ 12. Kh1 Nxg5.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Bc4 Nf6 3. d3 Nc6 4. Nc3 Bc5 5. f4 d6 6. f5 Nd4 7. Bg5 c6 8. a3 b5 9. Ba2 Qb6 10. Nf3 a5 11. Rf1
comment: Developing the rook for a kingside attack and protecting f2. If now 11... b4 then 12. Na4 and White can trade his knight for Black's powerful bishop.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Bc4 Nf6 3. d3 Nc6 4. Nc3 Bc5 5. f4 d6 6. f5 Nd4 7. Bg5 c6 8. a3 b5 9. Ba2 Qb6 10. Nf3 a5 11. Rf1 a4
comment: Now Black is prepared for ... b4.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Bc4 Nf6 3. d3 Nc6 4. Nc3 Bc5 5. f4 d6 6. f5 Nd4 7. Bg5 c6 8. a3 b5 9. Ba2 Qb6 10. Nf3 a5 11. Rf1 a4 12. Nxd4 Bxd4
comment: White should now play 13. Bd2 to help defend the dark squares on the queenside.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Bc4 Nf6 3. d3 Nc6 4. Nc3 Bc5 5. f4 d6 6. f5 Nd4 7. Bg5 c6 8. a3 b5 9. Ba2 Qb6 10. Nf3 a5 11. Rf1 a4 12. Nxd4 Bxd4 13. Bxf6
comment: Instead he begins an attack on the kingside.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Bc4 Nf6 3. d3 Nc6 4. Nc3 Bc5 5. f4 d6 6. f5 Nd4 7. Bg5 c6 8. a3 b5 9. Ba2 Qb6 10. Nf3 a5 11. Rf1 a4 12. Nxd4 Bxd4 13. Bxf6 gxf6 14. Qh5
comment: Threatening 15. Qxf7+. If Black now plays passively by defending the pawn with 14... Qc7 then his queenside attack would dissipate. If 14... Ra7 the rook would be tied to the defending the pawn of f7 and would be unable to support the queenside attack.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Bc4 Nf6 3. d3 Nc6 4. Nc3 Bc5 5. f4 d6 6. f5 Nd4 7. Bg5 c6 8. a3 b5 9. Ba2 Qb6 10. Nf3 a5 11. Rf1 a4 12. Nxd4 Bxd4 13. Bxf6 gxf6 14. Qh5 Rf8
comment: If 15. Qxh7 then 15... b4 16. axb4 Qxb4 threatening 17... Bxc3+, 17... Qxb2, as well as 17... a3 undermining the protection of the pinned knight.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Bc4 Nf6 3. d3 Nc6 4. Nc3 Bc5 5. f4 d6 6. f5 Nd4 7. Bg5 c6 8. a3 b5 9. Ba2 Qb6 10. Nf3 a5 11. Rf1 a4 12. Nxd4 Bxd4 13. Bxf6 gxf6 14. Qh5 Rf8 15. Nd1
comment: Passive but necessary.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Bc4 Nf6 3. d3 Nc6 4. Nc3 Bc5 5. f4 d6 6. f5 Nd4 7. Bg5 c6 8. a3 b5 9. Ba2 Qb6 10. Nf3 a5 11. Rf1 a4 12. Nxd4 Bxd4 13. Bxf6 gxf6 14. Qh5 Rf8 15. Nd1 b4
comment: If 16. axb4 a3 $1 17. Rb1 (Not 17. Bb3 axb2 18. Rxa8 b1=Q) 17... axb2 18. Bb3 Qxb4+.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Bc4 Nf6 3. d3 Nc6 4. Nc3 Bc5 5. f4 d6 6. f5 Nd4 7. Bg5 c6 8. a3 b5 9. Ba2 Qb6 10. Nf3 a5 11. Rf1 a4 12. Nxd4 Bxd4 13. Bxf6 gxf6 14. Qh5 Rf8 15. Nd1 b4 16. Rc1 bxa3 17. bxa3 Qc5
comment: Planning 18... Qxa3.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Bc4 Nf6 3. d3 Nc6 4. Nc3 Bc5 5. f4 d6 6. f5 Nd4 7. Bg5 c6 8. a3 b5 9. Ba2 Qb6 10. Nf3 a5 11. Rf1 a4 12. Nxd4 Bxd4 13. Bxf6 gxf6 14. Qh5 Rf8 15. Nd1 b4 16. Rc1 bxa3 17. bxa3 Qc5 18. c3 Qxa3 19. Rc2 Bb6 20. Qxh7 Qc5
comment: Bringing the queen back into play.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Bc4 Nf6 3. d3 Nc6 4. Nc3 Bc5 5. f4 d6 6. f5 Nd4 7. Bg5 c6 8. a3 b5 9. Ba2 Qb6 10. Nf3 a5 11. Rf1 a4 12. Nxd4 Bxd4 13. Bxf6 gxf6 14. Qh5 Rf8 15. Nd1 b4 16. Rc1 bxa3 17. bxa3 Qc5 18. c3 Qxa3 19. Rc2 Bb6 20. Qxh7 Qc5 21. Qg7
comment: Threatening 22. Qxf6.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Bc4 Nf6 3. d3 Nc6 4. Nc3 Bc5 5. f4 d6 6. f5 Nd4 7. Bg5 c6 8. a3 b5 9. Ba2 Qb6 10. Nf3 a5 11. Rf1 a4 12. Nxd4 Bxd4 13. Bxf6 gxf6 14. Qh5 Rf8 15. Nd1 b4 16. Rc1 bxa3 17. bxa3 Qc5 18. c3 Qxa3 19. Rc2 Bb6 20. Qxh7 Qc5 21. Qg7 Ba6
comment: Threatening 22. Bxd3 forking the rooks.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Bc4 Nf6 3. d3 Nc6 4. Nc3 Bc5 5. f4 d6 6. f5 Nd4 7. Bg5 c6 8. a3 b5 9. Ba2 Qb6 10. Nf3 a5 11. Rf1 a4 12. Nxd4 Bxd4 13. Bxf6 gxf6 14. Qh5 Rf8 15. Nd1 b4 16. Rc1 bxa3 17. bxa3 Qc5 18. c3 Qxa3 19. Rc2 Bb6 20. Qxh7 Qc5 21. Qg7 Ba6 22. Rf3 Bd8
comment: Black wisely takes time out from the attack to defend his own kingside.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Bc4 Nf6 3. d3 Nc6 4. Nc3 Bc5 5. f4 d6 6. f5 Nd4 7. Bg5 c6 8. a3 b5 9. Ba2 Qb6 10. Nf3 a5 11. Rf1 a4 12. Nxd4 Bxd4 13. Bxf6 gxf6 14. Qh5 Rf8 15. Nd1 b4 16. Rc1 bxa3 17. bxa3 Qc5 18. c3 Qxa3 19. Rc2 Bb6 20. Qxh7 Qc5 21. Qg7 Ba6 22. Rf3 Bd8 23. h4
comment: The pawn is threatening to queen in four moves. Is there any way for Black to stop it.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Bc4 Nf6 3. d3 Nc6 4. Nc3 Bc5 5. f4 d6 6. f5 Nd4 7. Bg5 c6 8. a3 b5 9. Ba2 Qb6 10. Nf3 a5 11. Rf1 a4 12. Nxd4 Bxd4 13. Bxf6 gxf6 14. Qh5 Rf8 15. Nd1 b4 16. Rc1 bxa3 17. bxa3 Qc5 18. c3 Qxa3 19. Rc2 Bb6 20. Qxh7 Qc5 21. Qg7 Ba6 22. Rf3 Bd8 23. h4 d5
comment: The classic counter to play on a wing is to open the center. If 24. exd5 cxd5 Black will break open the position with ... e4. Was it mere luck that Black had this stroke available? No, it was inherent in the logic of the position. When White played 6. f5 it left Black with the latent possibility of d5.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Bc4 Nf6 3. d3 Nc6 4. Nc3 Bc5 5. f4 d6 6. f5 Nd4 7. Bg5 c6 8. a3 b5 9. Ba2 Qb6 10. Nf3 a5 11. Rf1 a4 12. Nxd4 Bxd4 13. Bxf6 gxf6 14. Qh5 Rf8 15. Nd1 b4 16. Rc1 bxa3 17. bxa3 Qc5 18. c3 Qxa3 19. Rc2 Bb6 20. Qxh7 Qc5 21. Qg7 Ba6 22. Rf3 Bd8 23. h4 d5 24. h5 dxe4 25. dxe4 Qg1+ 26. Kd2 Be7
comment: Clearing the file for the rook.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Bc4 Nf6 3. d3 Nc6 4. Nc3 Bc5 5. f4 d6 6. f5 Nd4 7. Bg5 c6 8. a3 b5 9. Ba2 Qb6 10. Nf3 a5 11. Rf1 a4 12. Nxd4 Bxd4 13. Bxf6 gxf6 14. Qh5 Rf8 15. Nd1 b4 16. Rc1 bxa3 17. bxa3 Qc5 18. c3 Qxa3 19. Rc2 Bb6 20. Qxh7 Qc5 21. Qg7 Ba6 22. Rf3 Bd8 23. h4 d5 24. h5 dxe4 25. dxe4 Qg1+ 26. Kd2 Be7 27. Rc1 Rd8+ 28. Kc2 Qe1
comment: Threatening 29. Qd2+ 30. Kb1 Rg8+ 31. Kh1 Qxc1#.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Bc4 Nf6 3. d3 Nc6 4. Nc3 Bc5 5. f4 d6 6. f5 Nd4 7. Bg5 c6 8. a3 b5 9. Ba2 Qb6 10. Nf3 a5 11. Rf1 a4 12. Nxd4 Bxd4 13. Bxf6 gxf6 14. Qh5 Rf8 15. Nd1 b4 16. Rc1 bxa3 17. bxa3 Qc5 18. c3 Qxa3 19. Rc2 Bb6 20. Qxh7 Qc5 21. Qg7 Ba6 22. Rf3 Bd8 23. h4 d5 24. h5 dxe4 25. dxe4 Qg1+ 26. Kd2 Be7 27. Rc1 Rd8+ 28. Kc2 Qe1 29. Rf2 Ba3
comment: The White king is surrounded.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Bc4 Nf6 3. d3 Nc6 4. Nc3 Bc5 5. f4 d6 6. f5 Nd4 7. Bg5 c6 8. a3 b5 9. Ba2 Qb6 10. Nf3 a5 11. Rf1 a4 12. Nxd4 Bxd4 13. Bxf6 gxf6 14. Qh5 Rf8 15. Nd1 b4 16. Rc1 bxa3 17. bxa3 Qc5 18. c3 Qxa3 19. Rc2 Bb6 20. Qxh7 Qc5 21. Qg7 Ba6 22. Rf3 Bd8 23. h4 d5 24. h5 dxe4 25. dxe4 Qg1+ 26. Kd2 Be7 27. Rc1 Rd8+ 28. Kc2 Qe1 29. Rf2 Ba3 30. Qg4
comment: Returning to protect the king, but it is too late.
